description: From Middle English abyden, from Old English ābīdan (“to abide, wait, remain, delay, remain behind; survive; wait for, await; expect”), from Proto-Germanic *uzbīdaną (“to expect, tolerate”), equivalent to a- +‎ bide. Cognate with Scots abide (“to abide, remain”), Middle High German erbīten (“to await, expect”), Gothic 𐌿𐍃𐌱𐌴𐌹𐌳𐌰𐌽 (usbeidan, “to expect, await, have patience”). The sense of pay for is due to influence from aby.

verbs.description: abide (third-person singular simple present abides, present participle abiding, simple past abode or abided, past participle abode or abided or (rare) abidden)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To endure without yielding; to withstand. [from mid-12th c.]
examples: Synonyms: hold on, resist, persevere; see also Thesaurus:persevere
The old oak tree abides the wind endlessly.
Synonyms: brook, put up with, tolerate; see also Thesaurus:tolerate
"I never could abide shoemakers," said an old servant,—and it ended in her marrying one.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To pay for; to stand the consequences of. [from late 16th c.]
Used in a phrasal verb: abide by (“to accept and act in accordance with”).
examples: The new teacher was strict and the students did not want to abide by his rules.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To wait in expectation. [mid-12th–mid-17th c.]
examples: Synonyms: hold on, stay; see also Thesaurus:wait

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To pause; to delay. [from ca. 1150—1350 to mid-17th c.]
(intransitive, archaic, Scotland) To stay; to continue in a place; to remain stable or fixed in some state or condition; to be left. [from ca. 1150—1350]
(intransitive, archaic) To have one's abode. [from ca. 1350—1470]
examples: Synonyms: dwell, live, reside; see also Thesaurus:reside

entries.meaning: (intransitive, archaic) To endure; to remain; to last. [from ca. 1350—1470]
(transitive, archaic) To stand ready for; to await for someone; watch for. [from early 12th c.]
examples: Synonyms: await, wait for; see also Thesaurus:wait for

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To endure or undergo a hard trial or a task; to stand up under. [from ca. 1150—1350 to early 18th c.]
(transitive, archaic) To await submissively; accept without question; submit to. [from ca. 1350—1470]
